Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: How csproj to custom vaild signatures time?" (#8918) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

https://github.com/andersnm/ExcelNumberFormat/issues/34

Hi @andersnm ,
For all clients, and I downloaded from NuGet official website and tested yesterday, you can use below CLI to test
```
dotnet nuget verify  "C:\Users\Wei\Downloads\excelnumberformat.1.1.0.nupkg"
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12729184/147842468-6584fa92-90a8-4227-a508-a8b7651354de.png)

Default clients will not use `nuget verify -signatures`, so system will ignore this error. But high level security company like government level they will use it, and it will upgrade to build error.


---

How csproj to custom vaild signatures time?
It looks like 2 years vaild time default, we would like to extend to 4 years.

### The Elevator Pitch

```
PS C:\Users\Wei> dotnet nuget
NuGet Command Line 6.0.0.280
```

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "ServerCommon and NuGet.Client libraries updated." (#8890) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
* ServerCommon Libraries updated to 2.94.0.
* NuGet.Client Libraries updated to 6.0.0.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Tests] Migrate existing Gallery Functionaltests to use a newer technology." (#8916) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Our WebUITests projects uses legacy technology `MSTestV1`, this caused problems with binding redirects (please see: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8890). There might be more problems caused for this legacy framework so moving to a newer technology or upgrading it would help us improving our processes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: [Bug Bash] The package recommended from IntelliCode should have the recommend icon on the left of the package in Browse Tab" (#11474) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

 NuGet Client Dev\6.1.0.86

### Worked before?

No

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

### Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\6.1.0.86
VS Version: Main\32030.25
OS: Windows-11-Enterprise-21H2
### Detailed repro steps
1. Launch VS and click “Create a new project” button in the G2C dialog.
2. Type “ASP.NET Web” in the search box, select the “ASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework)” template in the list and click “Next” button.
3. Type a project name and click “Create” button.
4. Select “Single Page Application” and click “Create” button.
5. Open the PM UI of the project and go to Browse tab.
### Expected
The package recommended from IntelliCode should have the recommend icon (the start icon) on the left of the package in Browse Tab.
### Actual
The package recommended from IntelliCode doesn’t have the recommend icon (the start icon) on the left of the package in Browse Tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/147820066-ae747e55-25b3-4a85-9cdd-765b8977ccf8.png)
### Note
It’s not a regression.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Handle cancelled CancellationTokens in PM UI when changing selection" (#11473) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

17.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Open a solution and PM UI, then change the selected package quickly (when using a slow package source?).  [PackageManagerControl.xaml.cs runs an async method with a cancellation token](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/bc11fd124fd87b55532742db2a56f4a324288bcb/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Xamls/PackageManagerControl.xaml.cs#L1003-L1005), but the async method lets the OperationCancelledException propegate to `PostOnFailure`. It should not.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: [Pack] No restore info shows in the CLI when running command “dotnet pack --no-dependencies”" (#11430) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

Dotnet SDK Version: 6.0.200-preview.21573.3

### Worked before?

Worked on Dotnet SDK Version: 5.0.200-preview.21077.7

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context
#### Details about the problem
VS Version: Main\32002.62
NuGet Version: Dev\6.1.0.68
OS Version: Windows-11-Enterprise-21H2

#### Repro steps
1. Create a solution with two C# ClassLibrary (.NET 6.0) projects.
2. Make the project1 reference project2.
3. Open CLI and go to the path of above solution. 
4. Run the command “dotnet pack --no-dependencies”.

#### Expected
There should be only one restore info for the project1 (like “Restored …\project1.csproj”) in the CLI as the [dotnet pack doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-pack?tabs=netcore2x) said as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144576288-05eaf5af-6a0c-45d0-8589-cee8ca699ebd.png)
Worked on Dotnet SDK Version: 5.0.200-preview.21077.7 as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144578096-dee6cfd5-8e08-41e5-a096-39896ef99dbf.png)

#### Actual
No restore info shows in the CLI as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/144576551-8f50c3a2-6e0f-41b5-99ed-ad1b69e14b6e.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stop using PublicAPIAnalyzer on projects that are MSBuild tasks" (#11470) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`NuGet.Build.Tasks` and `NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack` are projects that pack into packages that provide NuGet's MSBuild target functionality. `NuGet.Build.Tasks.Console` is a console app, used by `NuGet.Build.Tasks`, to provide restore using a different MSBuild API. None of these are libraries intended for customers to use as APIs in their own projects, and for at least one of these projects, when included with a `PackageReference`, the assemblies are not referenced by defaults, so customers must intentionally go out of their way to try to invoke it as an API.

In any case, we won't provide any API or ABI compatibility guarantees for the assemblies, only the MSBuild target experience. Hence we don't need the public API analyzer.
